76e76d14-85c3-41c4-b68f-234cf54db027.name: Samuel Arcadinho
76e76d14-85c3-41c4-b68f-234cf54db027.bio:
I am a researcher dedicated to advancing the fields of machine learning and natural language processing (NLP), with a particular focus on tackling real-world challenges such as data imputation, SQL generation, and the development of efficient model architectures. My recent work includes innovative methods for imputing missing values in multivariate time series data using Expectation Maximization over dynamic Bayesian networks, which significantly outperforms traditional regression-based approaches, especially for categorical variables.

In the realm of SQL generation, I developed T5QL, a method that enhances performance using smaller language models while ensuring the validity of generated SQL through context-free grammar constraints. This work addresses the limitations of current state-of-the-art methods that rely heavily on large language models (LLMs), making SQL generation more accessible and efficient.

Additionally, I have explored the evaluation of tool-augmented LLMs as conversational AI agents, creating a test generation pipeline that leverages intermediate graphs to ensure grounded and diverse test scenarios. My efforts in this area culminated in the ALMITA dataset, which provides a robust framework for assessing AI agents in customer support contexts.

I am also passionate about improving low-code platforms by enabling natural language queries for database retrieval, resulting in a significant increase in user engagement and adoption rates. Lastly, I introduced the Receptance Weighted Key Value (RWKV) architecture, which merges the strengths of transformers and recurrent neural networks, achieving remarkable efficiency and performance in sequence processing tasks. My work aims to bridge the gap between computational efficiency and model performance, paving the way for more effective machine learning solutions.

29f1270f-b290-42c3-a6a3-46b3df240b67.name: David Aparicio
29f1270f-b290-42c3-a6a3-46b3df240b67.bio:
I am a researcher dedicated to enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of customer support systems through advanced machine learning techniques. My recent work focuses on intent detection, where I developed a scalable system that combines a generic model with client-specific intent lists. This approach not only reduces training and maintenance costs but also adapts seamlessly to the evolving needs of diverse clients, outperforming traditional industry-specific models.

In addition to intent detection, I have explored the evaluation of tool-augmented large language models (LLMs) as conversational AI agents. I created a test generation pipeline that leverages LLMs to produce diverse tests based on user-defined procedures, ensuring high coverage of possible conversations. This work culminated in the development of ALMITA, a curated dataset specifically designed for evaluating AI agents in customer support, revealing critical insights into their performance across complete conversations.

Furthermore, I have conducted a comprehensive survey on subgraph frequency counting, a fundamental task in network analysis. My survey categorizes existing algorithms, highlighting their strengths and weaknesses, and provides a structured overview of methodologies that can facilitate efficient subgraph counting in larger networks.

Through these endeavors, I aim to bridge the gap between theoretical advancements and practical applications, ultimately improving the way AI systems interact with users and analyze complex networks.

c89e4497-150d-4e75-abbc-3aa070dba88f.name: Mariana Almeida
c89e4497-150d-4e75-abbc-3aa070dba88f.bio:
I am a researcher dedicated to enhancing customer support systems through advanced machine learning techniques. My recent work focuses on accurately predicting the intent of customer support requests, which is crucial for enabling agents to respond efficiently. I have developed a scalable system that combines a single generic model with client-specific intent lists, significantly reducing training and maintenance costs while providing a personalized experience. This approach allows for seamless adaptation to the evolving needs of clients, demonstrating superior performance compared to traditional industry-specific models.

In addition to intent detection, I am exploring the realm of tool-augmented large language models (LLMs) for creating AI agents capable of engaging in realistic conversations. I have designed a test generation pipeline that leverages LLMs to produce diverse tests based on user-defined procedures, ensuring high coverage of possible interactions. My work includes the development of ALMITA, a curated dataset specifically for evaluating AI agents in customer support, which highlights the challenges LLMs face in managing complete conversations.

Through my research, I aim to bridge the gap between advanced AI capabilities and practical applications in customer support, ultimately improving the efficiency and effectiveness of these systems across various domains.
